segments.text: We're out on April 3rd.
We're out on Chick Lane.
And the sky is overcast.
Looks like it might be rainy.
And I'm about to have the great joy and honor of interviewing Dr. Frank Hubert, former dean and chancellor, and for me, seventh grade band director and twelfth grade principal.
Dr. Hubert, now check your, say a sentence or so and let's see if yours are working.
I'll take this moment to tell you that you need to go out to your van and turn your lights off.
Let's begin by your giving a biographical summary of your growing up and experience before coming
to A&M in 1959.
This would introduce any reader of this material later to your background.
All right.
Public education in Cameron and in Austin.
Graduated from Austin High School in 1932.

I entered the University of Texas, had a checkerboard career there, two years of pre-medicine, and then after spending a summer in Galveston living in a med fraternity house, I learned that medicine was not my cup of tea.
So back to the university, changed curricula,

graduated in 38 with a degree in government at the close of that period my undergraduate period i was in the longhorn band and when george hurt colonel george hurt came to the university to direct the band
I think in 1936.
He asked me to be the student assistant director and I was that.
And.
I had honked my way through the University on a tenor saxophone.
For that six year period.
And that was my musical background, essentially.
Hurt made me the student assistant, and I enjoyed that role very much.
Letcher Stark, a philanthropist from Orange, Texas, and at that time chairman of the Board of Regents of the University of Texas, asked Hurt to come down to Orange one summer and
to provide a summer training program for his two musical organizations, a girls drum and bugle corps, the Bengal Guards, and a boys band.
The band was in a transition period and searching for a new director.
Hurt recommended me.
I went down for an interview, was employed by Mr. Stark, although I was a full-time member of the faculty.
My salary came from Lutch Stark Boys Incorporated, a charitable corporation.
Began my teaching career there.
six years into the spring of 44, and I went into WWII late in the war.
It got to the point where most of my friends in Orange, Mary Julia and I, many couples, the guys were being drafted
and there were some with one and two children.
I wasn't drafted.
I told Mr. Stark, I can't wait here while all of these guys are going, so I'm going to ask for voluntary induction.

he said well i wish you'd wait till the end of the school year the reason is that governor coke stevenson is going to make our commencement address i said mr stark my burning ambition is that i've got to go to the service he said well i'll understand that so i did a couple of years in the military
during which time I started correspondence courses on a master's degree at the University of Texas in school administration.
After the war, went back with my GI Bill, one year at UT, finished my master's, and let's see, that year was 46.
J.W.
Edgar at that time was superintendent of schools in Orange.
And I had had a course the summer of 46 in which Dr. Edgar was enrolled.
He was working on his doctorate at that time.
It was a course in elementary education.
At the end of the summer, he invited me to come to Orange
This is now 46.
As an elementary principle of Tilly School in Riverside Edition.
That's T-I-L-L-E-Y.
Yes.
And I accepted.
Mary Julia and I and Hank.
At that time, our...
three, oh, five-year-old.
Hank was born in 41, and this is 46.
Our five-year-old hopped in the car and headed out for Orange.
During our ride to Orange, T.P.
Baker, who was then principal of the high school,
Accepted a job in Austin as principal of the Austin High School.
And at that time, Doctor Edgar asked.
Doctor Edgar, was he still Superintendent then?
Or was it Chandler?
Edgar Edgar was Superintendent then Edgar asked.
WT Barrett, Edgar asked WT Barrett, who had been assistant principal, to take the principal's job.
Barrett, with whom I had lived in a rooming and boarding house in Orange during my band director years and before my marriage in 1940,
Barrett asked Doctor Edgar if he could have me as an assistant principal.
Edgar said yes, so I never did get to.
Operate as an elementary principle.
I moved into the high school as an assistant principal.
One year, Barrett went to Odessa.
I moved into the principal's office.
Just at the time when Edgar was moving to Austin.
As a Superintendent and the new Superintendent, CEO Chandler.
told me, Frank, we can't afford an assistant principal again.
You're going to have to be the principal and the assistant principal.
I agreed, of course.
And that year was probably the most heavily loaded work year I've ever had.
But nonetheless, at the end of 48,
had an offer from the University of Texas to accept a research fellowship in the College of Education, working with J.G.
Umstadt, a specialist in secondary education, and with Henry Otto, a nationwide, international, in fact, recognized guy in the field of elementary education.
Uh, to accept this research fellowship.
To start doing a.
Start developing a procedure for the.
Uh, for a school district wide evaluation program.
Up to that time, only the high schools were evaluated for Southern Association purposes and other purposes.
The elementary schools weren't into the act.
So it was an opportunity to have the support from that fellowship along with my remaining GI Bill eligibility.
And I accepted that fellowship, married Julia Hank, and by this time,
Mary Catherine, who was born that year in 48.
We moved to Austin, lived in the Bracken Ridge Apartments out near Lake Austin, a veteran's village.
And it was there that I finished my doctoral program.
During the course of that time, there was in the Texas legislature
a momentous piece of legislation for Texas public education entitled the Gilmer-Akin legislation.
And it revised the entire system of financing public education in Texas and revised the governance of public education in Texas from the state level.
It did place a heavy.
The legislation did place a heavy commitment to local control.
Education.
I was asked to.
to work with a nucleus group before Governor Buford Jester of Corsicana, before Governor Jester signed the Gilmer-Akin legislation in June the 9th of 49.
I was, a couple of weeks before that time, five of us.
Read the legislation and began developing the processes and procedures, the forms, the applications, the rules and regs by which the Gilmer education Gilmer Aiken education would become operative.
After that experience, Doctor Edgar was selected as Commissioner of Education.
So he inherited me for the second time.
I was already band director when he became superintendent in Orange, and then this time in Austin.
I went to work for the state education agency when it was organized, the new education agency, and stayed there until 55.
Had a call from
W.B.
Butler, chairman of the board of trustees for the Orange School District.
Bill Butler was O.D.
Butler's brother.
Asked me to come down and interview the board regarding the superintendency in Orange.
I went down.
had the interview and was offered the position and accepted it.
Before I went down, while still in Austin, I had a call from Mr. Stark.
And he said, Frank, I know that you either have been or will be offered the superintendency in Archer.
I just want to invite you to accept it.
We'd like to have you back down here.
I expect with his nomination and the support of the board, I became superintendent there in, I think in January of 55.
Stayed until 59 when I had a call from Earl Rudder, vice president of A&M College of Texas.
He invited me to come to
College Station.
Visit with him.
Tom Harrington.
Then the president of the system.
And the University.
And meet with the board.
With the view in mind of becoming the Dean of the School of Arts and Sciences.
At the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas.
Mary Julia and I drove up for the interview, spent the day.
I was interviewed by President Rudder, by Vice President Rudder.
This was in May, incidentally, of 59.
Vice President Rudder, Tom Harrington, the president, Boyd, the vice president for academic affairs.
The name escapes me, I'll pick it up later.
And then at 2 o'clock that afternoon, met with a board of directors.
Sterling Evans presided as chairman.
Other members whom I recall are S.M.
Wittenberg of Amarillo, the Fort Worth guy.
Maggie McGee?
No.
I'll pick this one up later also.
In these conversations, interviews, what did you perceive they thought they were looking for?
What did they think they needed?
Well, that really wasn't revealed as clearly as I came to learn a few weeks later.
It was apparent that they wanted someone from the public education sector.
Why, I wasn't certain.
I didn't know why, but it was clear that they did.
During the interview, they asked me numerous questions regarding the transition of students, male students,
from the high school period to the universities of our state.
And what happened to them?
What prompted them in their selection of a university?
It was at this time, incidentally, that A&M was at a
at a plateau in terms of its enrollment.
Fewer than 7,000, all male, all military.
They did not ask me any questions regarding military or coeducation.
They did ask me some questions about my experience as a member of the Committee of 75 at the University of Texas.

That committee had been appointed by the Board of Regents at the University of Texas, 75 persons from Texas and elsewhere, to make recommendations to the Board of Regents there regarding the nature of the university on its 75th anniversary about 10 or 12 years down the road.
I didn't know it, but at that time Texas A&M was considering a similar study.
And I think it was my experience on that committee of 75, which they picked up from my curriculum vitae, that they asked me questions about that procedure.
You're inferring that your connection with the University of Texas was in no way a disadvantage.
No.
In no way.
In fact, it was an advantage.
My experience with the Committee of 75 was definitely an advantage.
Because later on, after I came on board at A&M, President Rutter asked me to chair the Coordinating Committee for the Century Council.
More about that later, I expect.

uh went back to orange married julie and i told our son hank we got there just before curtain of the senior play hank was a senior told him that we were moving to a m he says well good for you i'm moving to rice he had just gotten noticed that day that he had been accepted at rice
Okay, so we made the move to College Station.
Let me ask a trivia question.
This is the last time we'll talk money.
What was the beginning salary offer?
I think, Haskell, the beginning salary offered by A&M was $13,200.
I took a $600 cut to make the move and orange my salary.
Would have been beginning in the 59 year.
13 eight had you and Mrs Hubert known the rudders when y'all were in Austin and they were in Austin.
I think I had met Margaret.
We did.
We did not know Mr Rudder.
I knew that he was land Commissioner.
I had seen him before.
in the elevator of the state office building at the corner of 12th and Brazos streets.
That building was shared by the Texas Education Agency staff and the Land Commission of Texas.
And I think I rode the elevator a couple of times with him.
Was it clear in the interview that he was going to have the title president very soon?
No.
Oh.
Not at all.
I accepted the position.
And.
Began.
Reported for work July 1st of 59.
Let's see, describe describe your perception.
Of the institution at in those early months.
Well, let me say this, Haskell, first.

When it was announced that Hubert was coming to A&M College as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, there were some voices among the faculty of Arts and Sciences that were dismayed by that selection.
And I can understand that.

Here's a guy out of public education, no previous experience in higher education except through his responsibilities at the Texas Education Agency, coming in as dean of one of the four colleges at that time, one of the four colleges in A&M.

and there was there was some dismay and consternation over that appointment but i must say that to the credit of the faculty they were patient and tolerant and took a wait-and-see attitude and i think by the end of the first year
there was a good relationship between the dean's office, the heads of the departments, and the general faculty in the School of Arts and Sciences.
I think that existed.
I had had the good experience in the Texas Education Agency of being the director of the division
which had all of the state agency responsibilities with colleges and universities engaged in teacher education.
And that was every one of them.
And in fact, I had chaired an evaluation committee, which Dr. Edgar had established growing out of the legislation.

to approve the teacher education programs, not accredit them, but to approve them for teacher certification purposes and for degree purposes, because at that time, the salary schedule was attached to the degree one held and the year's experience of teaching.

I had the good fortune of knowing 95% of the presidents of colleges and universities in Texas, senior colleges and universities in Texas, many on a first-name basis, simply by virtue of the experience of having been on their campus for three days to a week
chairing an evaluation team, and in their office practically every day during that period of time.
That was a rich set of experiences for me to take with me in this job.
And knowing the presidents, I also knew the principal academic officers of the institutions.
During my interview at A&M with Boyd Page, I asked Dr.
Page, I said, it's most unusual for
a university to go to a secondary school program and select a superintendent of schools to be an academic dean, especially in the field of arts and sciences.
Does President Rutter know?
No.
Not President Rudder.
Does Mr.
Rudder and Harrington and the board know what the consequences might be?
Have they considered that aspect of this appointment?
Page grinned and chuckled, and he said, yes, I think they've weighed at some, but they're willing to take the risk if they get the right person.
I didn't know what the right person meant.
But nonetheless, I raised that question and got that response.
Well, I'm at A&M.
I'm the dean of the School of Arts and Sciences.
And let's see.
I learned at about this time, early after arriving at A&M,
I learned that then President Rutter, after I arrived there July 1 as dean, on that same date, Vice President Rutter was named president of the university.
Now, I learned that President Rutter had called J.W.
Edgar.
Those two had known each other principally, I think, because of having shared the same office building in Austin over a period of a few years.
President Lutter called Commissioner Edgar and said, J.W., I need to bring somebody to Texas A&M
who is knowledgeable about the Texas public school system and particularly the high schools of Texas.
We here at A&M need to improve our relationship with the secondary school sector.
Will you give me some names of people who might be prospective candidates for such a job?
And he said, I think, he said, the position I have open at this time is the dean's job in the School of Arts and Sciences.
Excuse all of this coughing, clearing of one's throat.
Dr. Edgar gave President Rutter two names.
One was Bascom B. Hayes, H-A-Y-E-S, with whom I had worked very closely in the State Education Agency and who was a close friend.
He and his wife Donnie and Mary Julia and I spent many evenings together, a dear close friend.
He nominated Bascom Hayes, who at that time, I believe, was superintendent of schools in Freeport.
And he nominated me.
I was then superintendent of schools in Orange.
I think one of the reasons I was invited to be interviewed first was a degree.
I had a PhD degree.
Bascom Hayes had an Ed D degree.
In fact, when I decided to go back to the University and.
After WW2 and pursue graduate education.
I committed myself to a PhD track because I knew at some time if I had an opportunity to go into higher education, it would be much more valuable than an EdD.
Dr. Edgar recommended those two names.
I was invited first to be interviewed, and on the same day of that interview was offered the position.
And so that was the basis for my becoming a candidate for the position at A&M.
And that's a sketchy history of my before-A&M days, Haskell.
You got here.

in the summer of 59 what was your perception of the institution in those early weeks and months well first let's let's talk early weeks oh okay did you lie the first summer session i don't know what the enrollment in summer session was in
in 59, but my first impression of A&M was there's nobody here.
I could walk across the campus and not see a single individual.
Where are they?
That was a strange occurrence to me.
I came to realize that, number one, summer session enrollment at A&M was a downturn enrollment, and two, I had already known that the general enrollment at A&M had been slow to
change, and that became the basis for my concern about the all-male, all-military phenomena.
Over the long range, my perception of the university
as an all male, all military institution, was one of working within that framework and trying to do the best I could within that environment.
I recall my first experience at registration time in the fall of 59.
In those days, registration for the entire university student body was accomplished in one day.
One day.
All of the departments and colleges went to Sabisa Hall where tables were arranged.

by departments by colleges all around the hall students were first admitted by the registrar's office and then then they came into the hall to make out their their schedule of courses and we made every student's schedule during that one day of registration time and that was it there was a course added
additional time for ads and drops later on.
But registration was accomplished in one day.
I thought that was amazing.
There were long lines.
But they became shorter and shorter.
But the thing that was impressive to me was that the College of Arts and Science.
The school of Arts and Sciences faculty.

they were running uh each a member from each table would be running around what's the enrollment going to be what does it look like this year can you tell any difference are we going to make 7 000 well it was uh i think a great disappointment when when they didn't make seven thousand that seemed to be a goal out there somewhere
And, of course, at this same time, Mrs. Post, WWII, and the other colleges and universities in the state were skyrocketing enrollment, just going high.
Well, that was it.
Early on, I was introduced by President Rutter

as the new dean to a group of former students who were meeting at the msc i think there was a group of about 20 24 i don't know what unit it was from the former students but president rudder asked me to come over and be introduced to them as the new dean in the school of arts and sciences
I did and they asked me to make a few comments.
And I, without any temerity what so all, I said to the group, incidentally when I entered the room
It was a.
Coffee break period and all of the talk was.
Football.
Small groups here and here and here football.
Well, with no temerity at all, I I suggested in a very pleasant.
I think diplomatic and tactful way.
Let.
I had come to Texas A&M to accept this position because of my strong belief in a good, sound academic program at a major university.
I said, I think the potential is here, albeit I've been here such a short time, the potential is here for great improvement in that direction.
I would hope that the former students would turn their attention to a concern for the
for the academic development and improvement at the university.
I didn't say give it as much attention as you do athletics.
I didn't even mention the word.
But I did put in a plug for the academic side of the house for quality faculty.
What was their reaction?
That was it.
The reaction was favorable, really favorable.
I think I saw a few startled faces when I made this opening, but I do think that the reaction was very favorable.
President Rutter didn't comment on my remarks, but I didn't expect him to.
At any rate, that was my first introduction to a former student group.
And my perception was that
That the general tenor, the general feeling in the School of Arts and Sciences principally among the faculty was that we are basically a service institution.
agricultural and mechanical college is not likely to open up for the arts, humanities, and except as it's important to engineering, the sciences.
Incidentally, let me tell this story about one of our department heads in the College of, in the School of Arts and Sciences.
I learned during my first year here that Chester Klippel, head of the mathematics department, they're so a great guy, kind.
I learned that

when the College of Engineering would put into their degree program an advanced course in some engineering class that required a heavy support of mathematics, he would go audition that course for the entire semester.
Sit in the classroom.
with the students to find out just what kind of mathematics that course required.
And if it required an adjustment to the curriculum in the Department of Mathematics, he'd go back and make that adjustment.
I thought that was fantastic from the standpoint of taking the responsibility of providing service courses seriously.
In my, I wished I had located a copy of it, but I haven't.
I'm talking about a copy of my first meeting, a copy of my speech comments to the faculty in the School of Arts and Sciences at my first meeting with them.
I think it was in October of 59.
I was very apprehensive before that meeting.
I didn't really know what to expect.
I had a prepared speech.
I've got a copy of it somewhere.
I want to find it.
But during that speech, I did make the point with some emphasis.
that the School of Arts and Sciences had two basic missions, the lesser of which was the service course situation.
But
I think I emphasize also that we needed to take that responsibility seriously.
And to say that good engineers needed good science and good English and good communication skills and so forth.
But then also that each one of the disciplines within the college had a right to prime time, mainly because of its disciplinary nature and the field of knowledge which it represented.
Without that knowledge, the campus would be incomplete.
And my perception was that the faculty really had been, I don't know how to, had been underappreciated for so long.
that they felt that way, Haskell.
I don't know whether that's accurate or not, but it occurred to me that among some quarters that happened.
When you completed your remarks, how did you feel about your success in getting the message across?
I felt okay about it.
Because I was with a small group, we walked not too far behind you as you walked back to the Nagel Hall office, and we thought that you felt you had gotten across the message you wanted to.
We were giving you a high mark.
Well, I remember C-squared Doak.
came up to me after the meeting dr duke was head of the department of biology he came up to the to me after the meeting and he says something like this uh i feel we're fortunate to have
You as our new dean, you have shown intelligence and tact and I'm eager to work with you.
